concept.title: Topics and information types
concept.shortdesc: DITA content is organized into topics, and the topics are categorized by information type. Each information type has its own authoring requirements.

conbody.p: A topic is a unit of information with a title and content, long enough to make sense on its own and be authored as a unit, but short enough to give users the answer to their question without breaking away from the problem they are trying to solve.

People need a lot of information to use comprehensive and complicated products effectively. By classifying (or architecting) this information into general categories (types), you can:
Make it easier to rewrite current documentation. It can more easily be reused somewhere else.
Design new information more easily and consistently.
Make sure you provide truly task-oriented information. The user wants to do something or learn about something quickly.
Make sure you provide enough detailed levels of information. Task orientation ensures only the needed information is included.
Make better decisions about what to include and what to leave out. Only the important information gets included.
Provide a predictable online access structure for our users. Consistent design helps users. They learn the interface once, then expect things to occur in a similar flow and arrangement across all the tools that they use.
Provide for complex search and retrieval of information.
Information types are covered in more detail in their own section.
